markdownRemark.html:
For those of us in the center of the universe, the New York City MTA has finally unveiled support for contactless payments.

Long awaited - Chicago has had contactless payment since 2013 - the new OMNY (One Metro New York) payment system went live last Friday across select transit lines.

Given the sheer scale of the MTA’s infrastructure and the number of customers it serves, there are a number of learnings to be had from how the MTA is rolling OMNY out.

Piecemeal Approach

Similar to how the MTA overhauled its payment system from 1992 to 2003 as it migrated from tokens to the magnetic stripe cards, OMNY is not expected to be fully implemented until 2023.

Trying to avoid the embarrassment Chicago suffered when its own contactless payment system, Ventra, launched:

A computer problem knocked 165 card readers offline, affecting 60 stations across the city. About 15,000 commuters were waved through without paying, according to the CTA.

  • Current swipe is expected to be phased out by 2023 as OMNY is rolled out across the system

  • Internal test with a few dozen workers and ramped up to 1,500 before going live at the end of May

  • “Deliberately small” pilot

  • “A team” is set up at 511, the state’s travel information phone line, to deal specifically with OMNY-related questions

OMNY Risks

  • http://web.mta.info/mta/news/books/pdf/1905201400CPOC.pdf

  • System

    • Variance in performance of contactless cards
    • Potential software/hardware anomalies
    • Network comms
    • Volume stress test

  • Customer experience

    • Market penetration of contactless cards
    • Changing customer habits and expectations
    • New transit transaction model (TTM)
    • Open payment transactions are sometimes slower. There is a risk that OMNY transactions may not achieve the required throughput at high volume stations
    • There are many contactless bank card manufacturing and personalization facilities worldwide, and performance of all cards has not been the same. Therefore, some bank cards many not be accepted due to system design variables or other reasons.
    • OMNY is an account based system, and customers will no longer see confirmation of fares charged at the point of entry.

UX Pros/Cons

  • MetroCards currently cost a $1
  • Any impact on “swiping it forward”

  • Pretax transit benefits?

    Meanwhile, commuters who sign up for pretax transit benefit programs through their employers learned that the information provided to Ventra isn’t secure. Human resources administrators who tried to log in to their company’s account kept getting other companies’ pages.

  • Allow users to use the same payment method across all transit options - subway, rail, or bus
  • Fare-capping policies? Impact on weekly / monthly fares? Sydney’s Opal card removed their weekly option, London’s oyster card, too
  • What will happen to status/vanity cards (see: SUPREME)
  • Interesting that customers will have to depend on both
